answers.answer: Hello,There are numerous conditions which can cause tingling and numbness in the leg and foot. The common causes are diabetes mellitus, peripheral neuropathy, sciatica, herniated disc and deep vein thrombosis. Tobacco ingestion can cause nerve damage and have many serious effects on our body. It is best to consult a primary care physician and rule out above mentioned causes. A medical evaluation is absolutely necessary for correct diagnosis and treatment. Keep me posted.Best wishes and regards!

question: Hi,I've been using smokeless tobacco (dip) lately, and I think I may have done something foolish that could have caused some nerve damage. I went for a 6 month dental cleaning last week. During the cleaning, the doctor did a lot of scraping along my gums, which resulted in a lot of bleeding.  Needless to say, I need to start flossing more.  About an hour after the cleaning, I went home and rinsed my mouth out some more because my gums were still kind of sore and would bleed if touched.  After rinsing, I put some smokeless tobacco in my mouth for a while.  Later that night, I noticed that my gums would still bleed easily when touched.  A few days later, I've started to get this weird tingling feeling in both of my legs and both feet.  The tingling feeling is in my thighs, lower legs, and feet.My question is:  Could some tobacco have gotten into an opening in my gums or bloodstream and caused nerve damage, which is making my legs and feet tingle?The tingling is almost like a vibrating/ticklish feeling in my feet and legs.  I'm sorry if this is a ridiculous question, and I am trying to quit tobacco use. Thanks.
title: Tobacco and Nerve Related Question
